thread.title: Department rejects Centrelink debt recovery scheme FOI requests
thread.title_full: Department rejects Centrelink debt recovery scheme FOI requests

author: Ashlynne McGhee
title: Department rejects Centrelink debt recovery scheme FOI requests
text:
It is one of at least eight requests the department has tried to reject. 
Two of the eight were lodged by ABC News journalists. 
In another request lodged through the website righttoknow.org.au, the department claimed it could not find any documents about the risks of the automated program. 
"All reasonable steps have been taken to locate the documents you have requested and I am satisfied that they do not exist," the department's FOI team wrote. 
But in a third case, the department said it was refusing the request because there are too many documents. 
"I am unable to reasonably identify what documents you want due to the volume of documents," it said. 'Too much work' to provide documents 
The department responded to Crikey deputy editor Sally Whyte with the same refusal. 
"Your request involves too much work for the department," the letter to Crikey said. 
The Office of the Information Commissioner (OAIC) has released a statement saying: "All Australians have the right to request access to government-held information. 
"The OAIC works with agencies and departments to help build a culture of proactive information disclosure and community engagement." 
The OAIC is responsible for providing guidance on the Freedom of Information Act and says on its website one of the purposes of the act is "increasing scrutiny, discussion, comment and review of government activities". 
"The powers and functions under the FOI Act are to be performed and exercised, as far as possible, to facilitate and promote public access to information, promptly and at the lowest reasonable cost," it says.
